issues.title: Simon Frost's feedback on -00
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [Relevant draft version](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html)
- [ML discussion link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/t0At1t9j2L9r5r1RrFFWQ3jFEjQ/)

> **Section 4** (Attacks). 
> 
> I understand and applaud your intent here, to ensure the best security considerations, but I wonder if an alternative approach would be a draft along the lines of Threat Modelling conditions for Remote Attestation? This would highlight the scenarios behind for attacks, who the actors are and some potential mitigations. Such a draft could then be referenced, much like the architecture is, in particular contexts for multiple drafts.
> 
> **Section 5** (Examples of Specifications that could be improved)
> 
> I would suggest that these are perhaps better raised in context to the drafts, as issues, so the relevant authors can debate them. Putting them in a separate draft may not give full overlap with all the right people.
> 
> **Section 65** (Examples of Specifications that are detrimental for Security)
> 
> I disagree strongly with this section. Both Multi Verifiers and CoServ endorsement distribution address real world issues. By suggesting that there should be no attempts to provide some standards that address these challenges you encourage custom and proprietary solutions that will inevitably miss some of the security considerations (or threat modelling per my previous suggestion). It is much more important that the problems are identified and appropriate security / privacy  considerations captured to avoid any proliferation of insecure implementations.

issues.title: Thomas Fossati's feedback on -00
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [Relevant draft version](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html)
- [ML discussion link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/hJkFGOeXhZjSezYQa3MYMv-EpCk/)

> Abstract
> 
> Providing "guidelines and best practices for writing security
> considerations" is a worthwhile aim.
> Unfortunately, the document in its current form does not live up to
> the expectations set out here.
> 
> §1
> 
> This section is phrased as if I-D.irtf-cfg-cryptography-specification
> is the basis on which this document builds.
> However, when I look at the active I-Ds and RFCs [1], I cannot find a
> single one that applies, i.e., one that describes "cryptography
> protocols and primitives".
> Either it should be made clear in which contexts
> I-D.irtf-cfg-cryptography-specification is considered applicable to
> RATS documents, or the section/paragraph should be rephrased to state
> that the work you aim to do for RATS is similar to that done by
> I-D.irtf-cfg-cryptography-specification in the context of cryptography
> protocols and primitives, or the reference should be removed.
> 
> [1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/rats/documents/
> 
> §3
> 
> You need to clarify which RATS documents would need to take Lowe's
> hierarchy into account.  I certainly can't see how serialisation
> documents such as EAT or CMW would apply.
> 
> §4
> 
> This sounds good and is within scope. Please expand on this by (at least):
> * adding clear descriptions of the attacks
> * linking to existing parts of the RFC corpus
> * providing concrete examples in the RATS context.
> 
> §5
> 
> This looks completely out of the scope of this document.  Please take
> these discussion points elsewhere.
> 
> §6
> 
> Since these use cases are real and will not disappear just because we
> choose to ignore them, perhaps a more constructive way to phrase this
> section would be: "When RATS roles are split across multiple entities
> (e.g., CoSERV aggregators, multi-verifiers), the additional security
> and privacy risks must be clearly highlighted and addressed by
> proposing effective countermeasures."

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> some of the attacks may already have been discussed in the context of existing RFCs, such as BCP 72 and RFC 9334.

> §6 "What are the security and privacy implications when a RATS role is split across multiple entities?"

issues.title: Carl Wallace feedback on -00
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [Relevant draft version](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html)
- [ML discussion link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/GT71TTuLLBJXQrzk1zi_N61rIdc/)

> I agree with the reviews from Thomas and Simon. The stated goals of the I-D are worth pursuing but they don’t reflect the content of the draft, which in large part is simply turning comments about several I-Ds that have not garnered traction on the mailing list into an I-D. Almost all of the content that is pertinent to the stated goals is provided in references on Research Gate. The non-stated goals that consume most of the I-D appear to be stimulating work on RFC9334bis and halting work on coserv and multi-verifier.
> 
> Ignoring the stated goals and instead focusing on just one of the perceived issues, in section 6, bullet 2, you are (still) asserting that an aggregator-design necessarily requires a new trust anchor and seem to imply that introduction of a new trust anchor is necessarily a problem. I challenged your assertion to no response in [1] and gave a key attestation-based example of how an aggregator may be useful in [2], also to no reply. I understand that it is your opinion that these use cases need not be addressed by a standards body, but others have different opinions. It may be that work like draft-jpfiset-lamps-attestationkey-eku-01 could be expanded to help address some of your concerns re: trust.
> 
> Procedurally, I do not understand why you have marked this as updating RFC9334. Most of what would potentially influence an update to RFC9334 is incorporated here by reference and is not written as an update at all.
> 
> One nit, the first sentence of section 6 should begin “I believe” since only one author is listed.
> 
> [1] https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/JkKLBiUwc7BSGnSciX4JT-GQKx4/
> 
> [2] https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/SSiqWGFg5tW0fjYLNgr7M8KaMu4/
> 
>

issues.title: Jun's feedback
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [Relevant draft version](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html)
- [ML discussion link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/LfPzsLghscaW0UKnV8GEHSs5jfA/)

> Regarding §3 of draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00, we respectfully suggest introducing a shared definition of the relay attack and diversion attacks.  This would help ensure that everyone is speaking the same language during the discussion. RFC 9334 already covers replay attacks in §10; therefore we would suggest to give more focus on the part of potential vulnerability of exiting mitigation methods for the replay attack. 
> 
> Usama, could you please post a concise definition of the diversion attack on the mailing list?  The slides [2] describe the attack as requiring the theft of the private key stored in the root of trust, which seems to contradict the root‑of‑trust assumptions made in RFC 9334.
> 
> Regarding §6, the multi‑verifier draft already contains (i) the use‑cases in §3 of [1], (ii) the security considerations in §7 of [1], and (iii) the privacy considerations in §8 of [1]. We have analyzed threats and given corresponding mitigations.  We welcome any additional technical feedback so that the related discussion can be productive at IETF‑124.
> 
> Please feel free to post your comments on the mailing list or open an issue on the draft’s GitHub repository:
>  https://github.com/ietf-rats/draft-deshpande-multi-verifier/issues

- [ ] definition of the relay attack and diversion attacks

issues.title: Yogesh's feedback on -00
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [Relevant draft version](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html)
- [ML discussion link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/ymBUmMWBRbj7erVXPAK9YOBzBIU/)

> I spend some time reading the draft and have following comments on:
> https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons-00.html
>  
> Title is Great: This can be a very helpful document as a Guideline for Security Considerations for any
> RATS based Attestation System
>  
> Section 1: I would not state an example which is of not much relevance for Security.
> Instead, I would write Motivation as to WHY one needs a separate Security Considerations guidance for RATS..?
>  
> Explain Complexity, technological evolution or any other good reasons which mandate this draft..?
>  
> May be explain types of Attacks(at a very high level as an example) that need special focus...?
>  
> Section 3.  Honestly, I am confused here with this section.
>  
> Why bring Authentication here ..? RATS can be a protocol, to Aid in Authentication Protocols but
> There are many Industry protocols to tackle Authentication ..?
>  
> Section 4:
>  
> This is where I would elaborate all the Attacks
> - which are relevant to RATS based Eco-System ..?
> - What is missing in RFC 9334, which we want to add here..?
> - Every document, from RATS needs to provide Mitigation Strategy and if not applicable for a particular draft clearly
> state why it is not applicable?
>  
>  
> Section 5:
>  
> RATS cannot specify a specific Identity Protocol, there are many for example W3C DID, X.509 based Identity and many more.
>  
>  
> Section 6.
> This section does NOT connect with the Intent what you have in Abstract. Honestly, this section can be removed.
>  
> Perhaps you meant that these documents, bring extra security challenges, and hence the motivation for writing new Security Document.
>  
> Simply stating that the listed documents increase Security Risks is not helpful.
>  
> The real-world problems need to be solved in a standardized way, what would be helpful is to state that these two documents bring new security considerations and MUST take care
> of all the threats elaborated in section 4. (This note can very well go in the Motivation section)
>  
> Hope the feedback is helpful.

issues.title: Carl's claim about Aggegator
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
Carl's claim:
> “There is nothing that prevents an aggregator from possessing a certificate from a trust anchor already trusted by a verifier.” 

I am not refuting your statement to be false. I just don't understand how it will be done in reality for confidential computing without falling into several rabbit holes, including but not limited to:

1. In which infrastructure does Aggregator run? Is it the same as Verifier or different?
2. Is the Aggregator running inside a TEE? If not, it is useless for Confidential Computing. If yes, then how is it provisioned with the certificate without having the Cloud Service Provider in TCB and how are the public attestation keys for Aggegator distributed?
3. How is Aggregator provisioned with the keys? Who owns those keys? How is that entity trusted?
